So...  How's Ever doing right now?

"At this point it isn't clear what any of us outside of Venezuela can do to help those inside the country - and this has been hard for me to stomach. Perhaps one of the best things I can do is to provide emotional support. Created by Henry Reich" Very interesting words. The answer as to what can do for those inside the country is simple: pray. It many not seem like a good answer for many, but I can argue the question was not a good one either. Socialism only sounds good because it gives the people a secular messiah: someone who will fix the problems (real or imagined) if only the people give them unfettered control on doing so. So the people give up all control over their lives and then act surprised when the problems the secular messiah creates is worse than the problems they had before, but that's not the difference that matters. Since all law abiding people willingly gave up their power to the secular messiah, only the outlaws (which would include other nations intervening, as, by definition, they are outside the law of the nation in crisis) have the ability to challenge the secular messiah. And since the secular messiah at least paid lip service to law and order, one should not be surprised that those challenging the corrupt regime are worse still. Since law abiding people have given up the worldly means of making things better by electing a secular messiah, the only recourse they have left is the otherworldly. So, however trite the answer I gave may seem, to those who voted in a secular messiah, prayer is the only weapon left.

A much better question, especially considering the state of crisis the Covid-19 has caused, is how to keep this disease afflicting Venezuela from spreading elsewhere? Again, I would recommend prayer. Christianity is the one and only institution that all socialist states in the history of the world have made a common enemy. It doesn't matter if you think Christianity is relevant, socialists are only truly united in their belief that Christianity is relevant. If they think prayer is a weapon they are vulnerable to, use it.

The other thing we can do is to stop pretending that "kindness" is the greatest virtue for man. We don't think giving our kids a shot is "evil" even though it is unkind because we act on what is truly the greatest virtue man has (when coupled with the virtue courage): "prudence". It is prudent for a child to suffer a small shot than to suffer pain, become deformed and possibly die from a disease the shot will prevent. There are things every government should do, and those that it should not do because the people should do it themselves. In an age when it is characteristic for people to vote their own government in, the people have a moral obligation to be prudent on how much power the government should have.

I could talk all day on things that we should or should not do based on the virtue of prudence, but all short term answers will eventually become outdated. Instead, I will end this with only one recommendation and pray that it becomes the spark that will light the fires of moral civic duty. My recommendation is for parents to show this video to their kids and point out 1) that this was a socialist country that suffers so and 2) how remarkably scary that the early stages of this civil unrest are parallel to our own situation and 3) how the socialist sympathizing media is herding our country into a socialist state. The suffering that will come from this "shot" of truth will be small compared to the "pain, deformation and possible death (not to mention the author's idea of "insanity")" that a socialist state will bring.

comment_text:
Hi Henry

I don't know if you still read comments here in this video, but just in case you were wondering, things are getting worse here. Maybe, thanks to your friend, you now have a better idea of what's going on here, but I know our case is one worthy of deep study, for it's a scenario the rest of the world is not used to, and this really goes back to at least the day after the fall of President Marcos Perez Jimenez (back in the 50's).

The thing with the getting used to that little bit of insanity is (in a very, very summed up way) because people here are "waiting for a shepherd to herd the sheeps" (a leader to guide the people in the streets so we can maintain a constant protest that will ultimately result in military power turning against all corrupt members of the actual government), but the only one who has showed capable of that (Leopoldo Lopez) is jailed in a military jail (Ramo Verde). The rest of the "leaders of opposition" are getting benefits from all of this mess, too, so they can't afford to get rid of the government until they at least have looted enough. This is something 70% of the people here actually know, and in other countries (maybe in yours), just 1/8 of the things happening here is enough for the people to rise against them and throw them out of the power. But because of the way politics handle things here, and the corruption, and the selfishness in general, no real leader after Lopez have had the guts to guide the people, or at least are trying to, but again, politics from both sides (government and opposition) are doing everything they can to stop the rising of new shepherds who can actually pose a real threat to their status quo. So, without a leader, the sheeps can't do anything but to keep on with their lives however they can, even if that mean getting used to a "little bit of insanity", waiting for the same shepherd or for a new one.

Anyway, the best thing you can do to help us is to spread the word among your people so everyone can know what's the real deal here, just like you did with this video, so thank you for your support, man. If you ever want to know in detail what's the situation of us venezuelans, I'll gladly tell you anytime. Again, thanks for your support.

hey chris, thanks for spreading awareness... wish i had seen this way back when this was happening. if you and Ever are still working together, i'm sure you must be aware of how the situation is now, i haven't seen many international reports on it lately though.
however bad things were back in '14, they sure have escalated now, that 50% inflation 2 years ago could very well end up being 700% by the end of this year. protests have really toned down since then (because you get detained and who knows what else if you're caught protesting on the streets), food and other important items are 100 times harder to get now, and we get daily 4 hour blackouts all over the country (which have been justified by the drought caused by El Niño, but its really being caused by the govt's awful maintenance of the energy plants, and of basically everything else, for that matter) which in some cases, are even longer, and more than twice a day, some people being in the dark for days at a time.
the govt keeps stepping over everyone and saying all kinds of crazy stupid shit to explain the crisis and putting the blame on everything else except them. these days the opposition is trying to do a recall referendum on Maduro, to get him off the chair, but if the people are really tired of Maduro and his gang's shit, they're going to have to really fight for it, since they're trying every dirty trick they have to either ''pospone'' the referendum, or not doing it at all.
i feel like this won't keep going for too long now, though. this situation can't be contained much longer, its right at the point of collapse, of unsustainability (if it hasn't collapsed already... well, to be honest, it has, scratch that last part). it either end in the govt leaving peacefully, or it ends in even more pain and suffering for the people, in bloodshed, i mean. and even if we DO get out this mess, im afraid it could take many many years for it to really recover, to go back to being the country my parents and grandparents talk about, the country where you could walk calmly on the streets at any time, go out wherever and whenever you pleased, get anything you needed and any quantity of it, the country everyone wanted to visit, the one many people from here and all over the world called home.
i have some hope left though, i dont feel like things are UNBEARABLY bad, but thats probably exactly whtat Ever was talking about.
I've gotten used to it... most of us have.
keep raising awareness if you can
let's hope we get out of this one

-policemen around the world has attacked peaceful protestors before. Police brutality is so widespread and diverse that it could have more to do with the psychology of their roles and hierarchy, and less to do with personality or even ideology

I lived through a similar situation back in Indonesia in 1998.  Back then I was only 6 years old and I get the 'quiet and complacent' part really well, because while it was very chaotic and uncertain during the early days, my family eventually got used to the chaos after a while.

Fast forward a decade and a half later, I'm now in the US and I've met lots of Indonesians here (some of whom had become US citizens) who are of Chinese descent and told me stories of how they fled the country during those times.  Now, I start to realize how bad things were back then especially for those of Chinese descent who pretty much had their whole 'Chinatown' torched and no single building wasn't burned.  It's pretty shocking how even today, if I asked people, who aren't Chinese, about what happened back then, most of them don't even remember anything besides it was scary.

While it's undoubtedly a desperate state of affairs and more and more Chavez and his legacy are being discredited it's against the backdrop of decades of previous governments who were corrupt and who kept the rural, largely native populations of Venezuela in abject poverty.
The only reason this situation could exist for so long and without the kind of economic chaos that we're now witnessing is because it was all done with the blessing of the US as those previous governments that favoured the priviledged minority also allowed US corportations free reign in their country, specifically allowing them unhindered access to their oil reserves.
So what does the US and global economy do when Chavez nationalised those resources? They immediately blacklist the country, and this is what's caused the economic collapse of Venezuela. Driven primarily from without, not from within.
Now again, I'm no huge fan of Chavez: he was pretty obviously undemocratic in many ways but simply look at the levels of inequality in the country under his rule. The gap between the poor and rich shrunk massively and literacy went way up. There's a reason the poor voted for him... he was the only candidate that would make any attempt to redistribute some of the country's wealth to them. He wasn't even close to being the perfect choice, but he was all that was available in this shitty world.
The only real conclusion to be drawn from this? The US, simply will not tolerate an independent South America which is what has begun emerging in the last two decades, and will do everthing in their considerable power to destroy it.

Thank you very much Minutephysics. Your video means a lot to us Venezuelans. Unfortunately our plight barely captures the world press’ attention and it goes on unnoticed by most people. Venezuelans have simply had enough of 15 years of gross governmental incompetence, corruption, lies, hate rhetoric, steady decrease of live standards and squandering of the oil wealth. Back in 1999 Chávez was elected chiefly to tackle crime, corruption and inequality but it is precisely in these very 3 things that Chavismo has failed the most, despite having enjoyed relatively high popular support (at least to begin with) and unprecedented high oil revenues (for most of the last 15 years oil prices have hovered around the 90 US dollar mark). Some of the regime’s defenders like to point out that extreme poverty has been reduced in Venezuela but the same is true in all commodity-dependent Latin American economies. During the last 10 years ‘right-wing governments’ in Colombia, México, Perú, etc. have had more success reducing poverty compared to ‘socialist’ oil-rich Venezuela. Regardless what the statics say, I can assure you that 15 years ago shanty town dwellers lived in shacks built with bricks and corrugated roofing; nowadays one finds people living in shacks built with cardboard and plastic sheeting – something never seen in Venezuela before. Infrastructure has collapsed for lack of maintenance. The regular blackouts are due to broken generators in neglected old hydropower plants and the non-existing planning to increase electricity generation to match normal projected consumption growth. The oil industry, traditionally one of the few Venezuelan institutions free of corruption and run as a meritocracy, was politicised with government cronies. The resulting expulsion of highly-qualified Venezuelan petrochemical engineers has benefited oil companies worldwide from Luanda to Riyadh and from Houston to Perth. One by one the oil refineries have been closing down for lack of maintenance and investment. The Chavismo has exchanged profitable petrochemical income for mere crude oil exports - and a large proportion of this crude is sold at heavily subsided prices to buy half-hearted support for the ‘Revolution’ by a motley group of nations that offer little in return to Venezuelans in practical terms. The irony of this ‘socialist’ oil policy is that has hugely benefited the ‘Capitalist and/or Empire’ Western Oil Industries who are only happy to process Venezuelan crude oil. To make things worse, Venezuela’s gas prices are amongst the cheapest in the world and the obliteration of the domestic refineries have forced the government to import gasoline at international prices– something it can ill afford. No wonder it has run out of cash despite the high oil prices. It baffles me how some people can still defend such regimen when facts speak for themselves (and let’s not get started on the obvious repression and suppression of civil liberties). Anyway, I've got carried away…I could go on and on. Thanks again for uploading this video – I appreciate it very much.

Thanks for taking the time to make this video. As a venezuelan who lives here since birth, and after seeing so much commie gibberish in the comments, I want to make things clear:
Aside from the sentimental soundtrack, none of the issues regarded in the video are distorted. There is a shortage of staple products, inflation doubles every year while the bolivar (national currency) devaluates, all forms of crime are rampant and take a weekly toll on hundreds of victims, and corruption is widespread in all areas of society, especially within the government as you can expect. This is the short overview of a situation that has gotten out of hand, which is the reason for the protests that have taken place nationwide during the last two months and a half. There is no such a thing as "US influence" on this whole matter, only incompetence from a demagogic regime (which, ironically enough, IS under Cuba's influence and that is an uncovered fact as opposed to unfounded conspiracy theories). The dissenters have no current leader since the former became a political prisoner; protests are now self-assembled either through internet social media (the only means of information that hasnt been censored by the socialist regime yet) or word of mouth.

Seeing all these paranoid, unpatriotic, self-hating, "leftist" morons in the comments baffles me to no end. I find it hard to believe that people who actually grew up in the first world and presumably had access to proper education could be this dense. Criticizing "misinformation" and "political propaganda" while disregarding the facts, throwing straw men and spewing out archetypal commie babble about CIA influence, fascism, zionism, etc., is an unmistakable sign of communist brainwashing propaganda per se. This is dangerous, since gullible people unfamiliar with this form of indoctrination might fall for their ludicrous misinformation and spread it anywhere else to enhance the commie circlejerk cycle. They disguise themselves as "critical thinkers" while condemning others for thinking critically. Their kind are known to support dictatorships in the Middle East and North Korea for no logical reason. Their ideals are untenable and their fallacious "arguments" deserve not even the slightest consideration or respect. Do not allow yourself to be manipulated by their bullshit. Let the world know the truth about Venezuela; that's the least you can do to assist our cause.

Hi from Caracas, 

Thank you very much for the honest video. It always helps when people abroad write something about Venezuela, specially when they leave things as an open question. References to Venezuela tend to get political quickly, with people 

I'm a middle-class software developer who (luckily) can afford a decent living and if it weren't for the very high crime rate (and that I should increase my income a tad more), I could say that I live as comfortable as most of my friends and family that have migrated abroad, specially since I don't have the problem of whether I fit in or not. I just am. 

I also read a lot of local and global history and try to see how our current situation fits into the grand scheme of country development throughout the world. We're technically a developing country, which means that our status is "underdeveloped". But the most fitting description is paraphrasing William Gibson. For those who see the glass full (I'm included), progress is already here, it's just not evenly distributed. But for those that expect the worse, the failed state is already here, but it hasn't reached everybody.

Your friend Ever is not wrong in explaining the situation. But we're not as helpless as "SOS Venezuela" can make others think. Last night the government met with the opposition and although there won't be immediate breakthroughs, the consensus is that most people in power don't want to let the country sink into anarchy. As for "at least I don't have to smell tear gas", I haven't either, even after moving through the city, going to a rally, to multiple neighbor meetings and dealing with people that block streets.

Ever is most likely young and waking up to a country he never imagined. He's probably wondering whether he should stay or leave. That's the decision many of us with certain mobility have faced. In my case, a brother and a sister left to the USA and me and my other sister stayed. Our lives are completely different but I certainly don't regret my choice, specially when the worrying news that reaches abroad is just a fraction of the big picture.

I trust the people here & I think we'll be fine.

Thanks for caring,

Tomas

Venezuela was never a socialist country, it is a state capitalist country. please don't confuse Socialism with Communism. Socialism is just a system where people choose to cooperate and the state has some ownership of things such as schools, hospitals etc. Of course it is not this black and white, a lot of countries mix several systems. I just want to point out that "Socialism" is not some menacing system that spawns chaos and dictatorships. A lot of the happiest and most prosperous countries in the world (Western Europe, Canada etc.) have "Social Democratic" systems that function properly.

Don't ever assume that all the problems in the country are because of the current government, people have to accept that the presidents before this revolution are the reason they exist in the first place. Don't be so arrogant, learn to criticize your self and to learn from your mistakes before criticizing others. Our society has almost hit rock bottom, because those against the government can't accept that both parties are humans and that it's both parties' fault that our lives have come to this.

You can't and won't change a country just by changing the government, you have to change yourself, change your ways and educate your children and the children of your children. Fight for your children because seeing a safe, economically stable, fair Venezuela, is very unlikely, I will probably die of old age before I get to enjoy of that, and I'm on my early 20s, but maybe my children will, concentrate on showing the youth the mistakes of the past, so that they won't be made again, concentrate on giving them good moral grounds, so that they won't be as corrupt and vain.

Don't blame, learn from mistakes and help the process of fixing.
Don't just complain, do all you can to change it.

I just want to point out that Venezuela's woes aren't the inevitable consequence of socialism, as some commenters have claimed.  Particularly since the usage of propaganda nor two decade long dictators aren't inherently socialist.  Such a claim is about as true as calling North Korea communistic (it's a totalitarian, authoritarian police state).  In fact, in countries where unmolested forms of socialism are in place (Canada, the UK and Western Europe for example), these countries have lower infant mortality rate(a common indicator of the quality of healthcare in a country(despite paying orders of magnitude less than an American for health care)), higher overall quality of life and lower levels of crime than, for example, the USA.  So please refrain from throwing mud like that.  Awful situations like this isn't a time to try and rub your opinion in smugly, particularly when your opinion is so obviously biased and ignorant of the situation at hand.

Hi Henry, I'm a subscriber since the rain video, I think. I'm from Venezuela, I live here, in Valencia (the third city shown here 0:49 ).  I'm a student, I study electrical engineering.

I learned english (mostly bc my mom wanted me to) and found you guys, Brady's channels, yours, CGP Grey, Destin, Veritasium, SciShow, Ideachannel, Vihart, etc. You guys are awesome. You are truly great. I mean, you share your knowledge with some nobody over the internet for fun, for science, for the progress of humanity. That's outstanding.

Your video made cry, just a little. It is really overwhelming that one of your favourite science stars take a whole video to show some of the levels of insanity that take place here. It's like Neil DeGrasse Tyson took a whole Cosmos episode to talk about it.

Even when there are no protests, there's no "normality". Peaceful life is really an utopy here. I mean everyday you go out to the street, there's an incredibly big probability you don't get back home alive (gangs, insecurity, impunity). Corruption. Inflation higher than syria's (even when there's normality) and they're on war. We're not. There's a mediocre judicial system. I believe people protest because of this rampant insecurity. Because we're supposed to be the richest country of the world ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves ) and there's no way to treat cancer, because there are no dollars to import (because we also, have no production whatsoever) the reactants necessary to do chemo. You can't even treat a common flu without bribing someone. Because, to a HUGE part of the people (and growing) there's no future, only demagogy and an empty ideological discourse. From both sides (the so called "revolutionary" and the so called "bourgeoisie").

Anyway, I wanted to thank you. Really, man. It means the world to me. Gives me hope. I want to study, graduate and work for science like you. Thank you.

There is hope, only because of people like you... Humanity is proud of you. Though we're not at our best, but the day we realise our mistakes it will be due to sincere efforts by humble beings like you. Cheers!

I live in Venezuela. I've also lived abroad. I'm not completely unbiased, yes, but I feel I can say with certainty that the "Rebels" (really, they're university students that have had enough) are the good guys. I could list all the evil and bad things that the government has done, but let's just leave it at recent events: pacific protests have escalated only because the government doesn't want to hear us complain. 

They bomb us with EXPIRED teargas bombs (which by the way, can be lethal in long exposures), they have killed with rubber bullets (one of our first victims, Geraldine Moreno, was shot up close with rubber bullets; wanna know what the autopsy said? There were some bullets - among the 10 or so that they extracted from the brain - that were impossible to extract, her face was a canvas of rubber bullets). 

I live in the Capital, right next to Chacao and Altamira (two municipalities), which becomes a warzone every night. Right by my house I see whenever the national guards pass by - not just one or two either, although by now I've given up on trying to count them. We use twitter to warn, and since I can't go protest I take it upon myself to try and be of help in that way. I've tried documenting when they go past, and among one of those times I wasn't discrete enough and was shot at by the guards that were passing by (I wasn't hurt, thank god, but my little sister of 7 is traumatized - it felt surreal, like a scene out of a war movie). 

For good measure, I feel I should also say that the government is very obviously corrupt: hospitals are totally run-down and are missing vital supplies - like the picture shows, only worse: Cancer patients have no way to getting Chemotherapy, there are no major surgeries because of damaged equipment, some surgeries have had to be done in the middle of a power outtage, and having to use cellphone lighting instead of the necessary lights to finish whichever surgery had begun. 

It's a sad, infuriating, situation.  Thank you for enlighting people on this subject.

Also, for anyone that would like to know, this didn't just start out of the blue: Recently (cuz it happens very often), an ULA university student was shot and killed in a street robbery, then not very long after there was an attempted rape at a University in Tachira. In that city, students made pacific protests to get justice for the girl and those who tried to rape her. Since the court wouldn't take the case, things escalated to what they are now: University students unite to protest for all that's wrong in this country (shortage of foods, supplies, the insane amount of crime that goes unpunished, corruption, etc).

If people only knew how complicated reality in Venezuela (and any other country that decided to take a different path other than the "establishment"; Ecuador, Argentina, Bolivia, Brasil) really is you people would be amazed.  
Here's a country that enjoys every type of natural resources known to man, not only do we have everything, but we have A LOT of everything. 

The problem with my country is a series of vicious circles starting with the way we are. We are all corrupt down here; we are raised since childhood not to be the town's idiot based on cutting in line, not keeping promises, lying, taking advantage of less fortunate people, always speculating (with the Dollar, with food, etc.). To give you a very simple example: Food, most of everything produced in Venezuela went to Colombia because that country can pay in US $; the same happens with gasoline & other products we produce or we used to produce. There's also a very strong international push, funding the opposition in creating chaos since the year 2000; the Chavistas are also to blame as they've ripped off more than half of the international reserves we used to have abroad (Gold & US $) & the list goes on & on & on... Corruption & social apathy is common currency in my country... We are the perfect example of what Cause & Effect really is in physical form.

We have a joke down here: When god created Venezuela he decided on giving it all the wealth the Earth could give; St. Peter looked at god & told him how unfair it was to give one country so much wealth & god replied: wait a second; hold on, chill out my good friend... I will now create Venezuelans to manage the whole thing. Then St. Peter understood his plan & laughed. 

It isn't funny at all as it has always been the same; third world is a condition of the mind, is a mentality, that mentality creates misery. It's a vicious circle. This asshole leaves office, another asshole will come, spread around some Arepas & people will follow like cattle to the slaughterhouse. It's all about special interests, new & old oligarchs, oil, oil & more oil... 

I know many of my countrymen/women will be pissed off at me; but the truth always hurts.
This is the future of Argentina.
